VulnerabilityDesc.Description: If a malicious user is able to inject malicious Javascript into a SVG file, then any user who views the SVG on a website will be susceptible to XSS.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Remove all user-input data from the SVG file or not generate the SVG at all

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: If the asset or collateral used in a pair is an ERC20 token with fees, the Convenience contract fails to function.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: The user has to adapt and cover the fees themselves. The convenience contract doesn't do that and thus always fails.

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: An attacker can frontrun to repay a single token for a user's debt, causing a DoS on every user that repays their full debt.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: If assetsIn[i] is bigger than due.debt set assetsIn[i]=due.debt and due.debt=0

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The callback to the msg.sender in the middle of the pay() function before important state changes violates the Checks Effects Interactions best practices and can be extremely dangerous.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: The callback should be placed at the end of the pay() function after all state updates have taken place.

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The safeName() function can cause a revert, making the contracts not compliant with the ERC20 standard for certain asset pairs.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Use the BoringCrypto safeName() function code to handle the case of a bytes32 return value.

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Users might pay enormous amounts of gas when a user mints new liquidity, if the pair doesn't already exist, it deploys it. Deploying a new contract on ethereum is super expensive, especially when it's such a large contract like TimeswapPair, it can cost thousands of dollars. Users who try to mint liquidity on pair that doesn't exist will end up paying thousands of dollars.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Revert instead of deploying a new contract if the pair doesn't exist

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The safeSymbol() function, found in the SafeMetadata.sol contract and called in 4 Timeswap Convenience contracts in the symbol() functions, can cause a revert. This could make the 4 contracts not compliant with the ERC20 standard for certain asset pairs, because the symbol() function should return a string and not revert.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Use the BoringCrypto safeSymbol() function code with the returnDataToString() parsing function to handle the case of a bytes32 return value

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: In the lend() function state updates are made after the callback. The lock modifier guards against reentrancy but not against cross function reentrancy. The callback before important state changes (updates to totalClaims bonds, insurance and reserves assets) also violates the Checks Effects Interactions best practices further widening the attack surface.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Place the callback at the end of the lend() function after all state updates have taken place

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: In CollateralizedDebt.sol, the mint() function calls _safeMint() which has a callback to the 'to' address argument. Functions with callbacks should have reentrancy guards in place for protection against possible malicious actors both from inside and outside the protocol.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Add a reentrancy guard modifier on the mint() function in CollateralizedDebt.sol

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Due to lack of constraints on user input in the TimeswapPair.sol#mint function, an attacker can arbitrarily modify the interest rate while only paying a minimal amount of Asset Token and Collateral Token.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Add constraints on user input to prevent arbitrary modification of the interest rate

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: borrow() function has state updates after a callback to msg.sender
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The callback before important state changes (updates to collateral, totalDebtCreated and reserves assets) also violates the Checks Effects Interactions best practices further widening the attack surface.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Place the callback at the end of the borrow() function after all state updates have taken place.

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Improper implementation allows attacker to increase pool.state.z to a large value
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: Even though a large number of zIncrease means that the user needs to add more collateral, the attacker can use a dust amount xDecrease (1 wei for example) so that the total collateral needed is rather small.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Make pair.borrow() to be onlyConvenience, so that zIncrease will be a computed value (based on xDecrease and current state) rather than a user input value.

VulnerabilityDesc.Description: The burn() function in CollateralizedDebt.sol should reverse the actions of mint() by burning the ERC721 token, but the ERC721 _burn() function is never called.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Add the following line in the burn() function: _burn(id);

VulnerabilityDesc.Type: Attacker can increase state.y to an extremely large value with a dust amount of assetOut
VulnerabilityDesc.Description: An attacker can set state.y to a near overflow value, then lend() to get a large amount of extra interest (as Bond tokens) with a small amount of asset tokens. This way, the attacker can steal funds from other lenders and liquidity providers.
VulnerabilityDesc.Repair: Remove the function or change it so that the caller cannot specify the interest they want to pay.
